General Philosophies of Muscle Mass Gain

Sample Diets

Calculate your Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE) in calories

Bulking Diet:
Calories: TDEE + 500 calories
Protein: 1+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Cutting Diet:
Calories: TDEE - 500 calories
Protein: 1.5+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Maintenance:
Calories: TDEE
Protein: 1.25+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Adjust calories as needed based on your goals / results.

I got 2 fitbit inspires for my wife and I at christmas. She's slightly overweight but crazy competitive so I just fuck with her about steps/heart minutes/miles etc and it's really motivated her to do better. I think having a visible metric to show you exactly how little or much you're doing can be a great motivator for some. The fitbit inspire was dirt cheap and lets you step into smart watch territory without investing an arm and a leg. That being said I've heard a lot of good things about Garmin, the accuracy of their metrics appears to be some of the best judging from user reviews. Fitbit's come with 1 year of their premium service though which is honestly really nice to have. If you haven't had one before my recommendation is starting cheap just in case it doesn't add anything to your life.

>Several studies, however, have found no evidence of protein toxicity due to high protein intakes on kidney function in healthy people.

>In people with healthy kidney function, the kidneys work continuously to excrete the by-products of protein metabolism which prevents protein toxicity from occurring.

>>69963869
Sugar and fast/processed food is definitely addictive. You have to mentally frame your cravings as the addiction trying to lure you to ruin. Whenever I eat crap processed salt/sugar/fatty snacks or drink soda on a couple of consecutive days, I immediately start getting cravings, but if I manage to push through for a few days without eating shit they go away. But it's interesting to notice how quickly the cravings appear after only a very short time, days, of eating that stuff regularly.

If you've been addicted for long it's become not just a physical but also an emotional addiction, a habit, so it's hard to break. It is hard! You can do it, though, but don't underestimate the cravings, ir think they're "natural". They'll go away once you kick the addiction

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69955312
Yeah, they are a meme. I actually came here to this thread to ask about posture, too. It's usually caused by a combination of tight and weak muscles. For example if you have a rounded back your chest, front delts and upper traps tend to be tight and need to be stretched, neck flexors, rear delts, and lower traps tend to be weak. For the lower body it's usually tight hip flexors and weak glutes. I would honestly focus on stretching the tight muscles, if you lift you will strenghten all muscles anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69959273
Some are better in the sense that they give better things like ROM, easier loading, lower risk, etc. That's true. They're superior in the sense of being easier to utilize. My contention though is that crunches effectively work the abdominals in a full ROM, they're easy to load, they are safe, they're available to everyone with no equipment, etc. They're just a good choice for anyone that wants to make ab gains. This is why they are a staple of ab building before people need progressions/more weight to continue to grow them.

Planks, however, are not as good, as most of the weight is being rested upon the elbows and they are not aggressively fatiguing the abs. There are also lots of other muscles that are recruited, but not sufficiently fatigued in order to stimulate growth when doing planks, leading to more overall fatigue but with nothing given in return. This is why planks are a meme

Crunches simply isolate the abs a lot better and are frankly more comfortable and easier as well.

>>69959344
The problem with cutting in general is that you'll lose a lot of muscle.

The answer to cutting is to only cut through fasting. Either eat nothing at all or eat at maintenance. Fasting puts you in the proper hormonal state to be able to successfully fast while losing only fat, but the hormonal state will only persist so long as you eat nothing. Even a few hundred calories a day could fuck up your hormonal state. In a 10 day fast, you'll lose around 13-15 lbs of body weight. 40% of that is pure fat. 60% is lean soft organ tissue that regenerates after you begin eating again. Your muscles are already being fed in that time and your HGH is cranked through the roof, allowing you to maintain muscles and even gain strength while eating nothing. If you continue to eat but you also cut calories, you won't have the benefits of the HGH increase or access to your organ tissues as a source of food and you'll break down muscle. There's a study done by the buchinger villhemi fasting institute that goes into detail about it if you want to check it out. Fascinating stuff really and it's the ultimate way to cut if you have the willpower

Stop bulking when you don't like looking in the mirror anymore. Simple as that. As long as you don't give up on your eating habits you won't regain your fat, thought that's a separate battle entirely.

>>69961408
>I'm just trying to lose my fat belly
Fat is lost in the kitchen, not the gym. It's simple. You gotta eat less calories than you burn, which means reducing your calorie intake. In simple terms "EAT LESS FATTY".
use this site https://tdeecalculator.net/ to figure out your TDEE, always choose "sedentary" as your activity level. These sites grossly overestimate exercise and it's a good habit to lose weight even at rest, at least for most people. Once you figure out your TDEE, subtract 500 calories minimum from it and a maximum of 750 (1000 if you're really fat/obese). This is now your calorie goal day-to-day until you hit your goal. If you want to gain muscle you need to eat a proper amount of protein to encourage muscle growth in-addition to lifting, otherwise if you're just interested in losing fat you need to just keep the deficit going until you're satisfied.

And most important: Stay consistent. Nothing's gonna change if you have a 500 calorie deficit for 5 days and then gorge and binge eat on the 6th. You can undo entire weeks of progress like this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Borger is not snack edition

>Who is /fat/ for?
For Gluttonous gobblers who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

Depends how "skinnyfat" you are. If you're above 17% bf you need to straight up cut first down to atleast 14%. After that go for maintenance with high protein and work hard in the gym. If you're a complete noob you'll be able to increase muscle mass for little to no fat gain for about 3-4 months. After that you'll have to switch to a small surplus of about 400 calories max. Don't go back above 18% bf and cut back down to 14%. Just keep doing that

Nah you're not losing it. Sometimes parts of your body get shuffled around because your body restructures itself to accommodate the way you lose weight. During this time frame you might lose 0-10% of whatever you were losing before weight wise. Your body will do whatever it needs to keep those cells in place too, even if it requires filling them up with just water for even fucking months on end but eventually it passes and you start losing weight again. Lardasses aren't really meant to lose 100 pounds in a years, your body has all sorts of shit in place to prevent this and this shouldn't be much of a surprise given that every doctor you've probably ever talked to recommended less than 1 or 2 pounds a month of fat loss except recently.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69959170
Are you doing keto? Your body needs carbs to start burning fat, if it doesn't get those from your diet it will break down muscle tissue to kickstart the process on its own (one reason why no bodybuilder does keto). A side effect of this is feeling like shit because what glycogen your body gets from this process is prioritised for your brain, a holdover from when food wasn't as plentiful as it is nowadays.
Another reason might simply be a lack of electrolytes because you eat too little, consider supplementing them.

-Do 16:8 or more daily fasting for about 2 months or do keto for a similar length of time if you don't want to feel you're starving or start losing muscle mass

> I want to do a longer fast, what do I need?
- Snake juice and peace
> What is snake juice?
- 1.5 tbsp salt, 1 tsp potassium chloride (nu-salt, no-salt), magnesium citrate/chloride (optional, check for epsom salts) to 2 liters of water
> I feel hungry!
- You shouldn't feel hungry after the first day, if you do and are new, try switching to keto macros and restarting the fast later

>Recommended macros?
- 70% fat, 25% protein, 5% carbs. Keep carbs below 50g total.
- P:E diet - 50% or more protein, <40% fat <10% carbs

>I'm sub 20bf, want to get lean, but don't want to lose muscle
- OMADEOD
>I'm sub 12% and not sleeping well
eat a tiny protein meal 3 hours before bed on your "full" day of the 48
>I'm gaining weight on OMAD
-You're FUCKING UP, weigh your meal components and record in cronometer (free). Add light cardio or standing or switch to OMEOD so you can continue to eat like fat pig.

>>69956020
they call it the knee snapper
said to have been patented in snap city
the way the bar is holding the knee is going to alter how the force is applied on to the knee
basically the force is downward, but the knee is halted, the body would naturally want to split the weight evenly down the knee. Instead the bar is being used as the counter weight meaning force will be applied laterally against the knees.
The knee is a joint evolved for downward compression, it's not designed for lateral forces. This is why you'll see common knee injuries in basketball players who experience more lateral force than is natural because of how often they halt their body's momentum which incites force along the lateral plane of the knee.
https://youtu.be/zmXIr5tmmVs

I'm a recently bald 24 year old. long story short, the last four years I've been dealing with rapid hairloss. I did the big three (min, fin, nizoral) and had nice results initially but didn't last. three months ago, I capitulated and started shaving my head bald.

three nights ago I was feeling great about myself. hit a new personal record in the gym and felt on top of the world. I've never been on any of the dating apps nor have I ever had a girlfriend, but I've occasionally used the website called photofeeler to get validation from women. feeling up for it, I took a picture of myself and put it on photofeeler. I waited about an hour to see my results coming in. I open up my browser with 8 votes and noticed my scores were much lower than they used to be. I went on my external hard drive and dug up past results. I came across a picture of myself that I took three years ago when I still had hair which was rated at a 9/10 by 91 female voters on the website. it was then that I decided to do an experiment. I took a better picture of myself bald trying to emulate the same lighting and facial expression of my hair picture, uploaded it to the site, and waited until I got the same amount of votes as the photo with hair did.

well, picrel is the results. went from literally a 9/10 to a 5.2 becoming bald. if that's not a kick to the balls, I don't know what is. moral of the story, try to hold on to your hair as long as you can guys. I'm unironically considering going out and getting one of those hair system things now. this is so fucking brutal.

Isolate it you dumbass nigga. Isometric holds are always good and you’ll get plenty of that from your pull days + farmer’s carries and any hanging, but you wouldn’t grow your biceps just through isometrics, would you?

They recover fast, so high frequency and volume with higher rep ranges is key. Hit them at least three times a week with isolation. Make sure to cover extension as well as flexion, so wrist curls (reverse as well), and finger curls. Avoid anything that causes sharp pain in your wrist, try different variations until you find one that works best. Do this for a year consistently and you’ll have bigger forearms than most lifters.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69959668
Back extensions aren't the same as RDLs but as a substitute they're not the worst option. Main difference is that they have a different strength curve, less tension at the bottom so it tends to be slightly more glute dominant than RDLs which are more hamstring dominant. Still hits the hamstrings hard tho (and strangely you get a hamstring pump, which is pretty interesting considering that never happens on RDLs). Good mornings are more similar to RDLs so if you prefer those you can do both (good mornings one day, back extensions on another), but if you don't like them either then you can just do back extensions on both days. Ideally you would do bar on back for full ROM and more difficulty due to the longer lever arm.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69959730
Back extensions complement RDLs extremely well
>RDLs hit the lengthened position, back extensions hit the shortened position
>RDLs have a lot of axial loading, while back extensions actually decompress the spine at the bottom (effect is exaggerated even more if you're loading with bar on back since the weight is now pulling on your back at the bottom)
>RDLs are less fatiguing than deadlifts, back extensions are even less fatiguing due to the heavily reduced loads
>Back extensions are extremely good for the erectors, which helps to keep your erector strength ahead so that your hamstrings remain the limiting factor on RDLs
>Back extensions also give you a sick posterior chain pump
IMO you should do RDLs on one session and back extensions on the other

>Advice for new runners
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- Once you can comfortably run 6 miles/10km, start thinking about a goal in terms of race distance and time, and look for a training plan for that goal (see below for suggested plans)

>Couch to 5k Guide
https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/exercise/running-and-aerobic-exercises/get-running-with-couch-to-5k/
>Sprinters Guides

>I want to run a fast 5k, 10k, half-marathon, or marathon
https://www.runningfastr.com/ (with goal times)
https://www.halhigdon.com/ (more planning necessary but more thorough workouts/explanations)
>Stretching guide
https://www.runnersworld.com/uk/training/beginners/a32172701/how-to-stretch-post-run/

posts.com:
>>69941461
You're 175? Unless you are a manlet bonelet like me you're not too fat, so you have hope.
You don't need to do a hardcore training plan to get good in 2 months. The most important thing is to spend as much time on your feet as possible.
Do a joog every morning you can (they will get easier over time, you don't need to kill yourself and you shouldn't). When that is done just try to rack up as many steps as possible woolking. It depends on how strong your feet are, but this is what will give you the strength to handle the distance without getting injured. You don't want to get plantar fasciitis or other injury. Don't make the mistake of rooning hard then collapsing into a sedentary pile the rest of the day. This is how you get injured. Woolking a lot will also make you leaner and more attractive to the grill. Good luck.

>I got a pain in my lower right abdomen
Sounds like spleen pain, happens when your body can't keep up with oxygen/blood demand from exercise.
Make sure you warm-up properly, reduce your pace until you find a pace you're more or less comfortable with without feeling the pain and work your way up from there.
As soon as you feel the pain coming stop for a bit and breathe a lot.
Eventually it will start happening less

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69962585
>I was told to not restrict my calories yet because it’d demotivate me.
After covid I woke up one day to see I went from 60kg to 75kg.
What I did was to go running every day but it still didn't put a dent on the fucking weight.
I modified the approach and started running BEFORE lunch, it may suck a bit as you may run while kinda hungry but this will guarantee you're forcing your body to eat itself to get energy.
After that you eat a good, plentiful lunch. Then proceed not to eat anything for the rest of the day. Simple as.
Meal intake after 4-5pm should be kept to 0 or the bare minimum, you do NOT eat at night. If you get too hungry maybe have some fruit or one of those zero calorie bars and be done with it.
This way I easily dropped back to an OK 65kg within 2 months and have kept my weight in line since.

They're important in different ways, someone who has a base level of competency in martial arts will almost always beat anyone who doesn't. But after that the more important factor is size. The dirty secret of martial arts is that it's just efficient application of force, a reasonably competent heavyweight will always beat a lightweight, even an elite one.

In real world interactions though it works a little different, humans evolved without martial arts or weapons. If you look at animal interactions the bigger one usually wins, and the actual conflict rarely takes place, the smaller animal simply capitulates without a fight, and that carries over to humans, >>69946096 is right.

And in the real world we have a saying in martial arts: "black belts bleed just like white belts." If your opponent has a weapon you're fucked period. Same if they have friends. Avoid the situation and if shit goes down run if you can.

>>69945822
Pretty much anything will work if you combine progressive overload with proper sleep and diet in a consistent manner. HIT may or may not be an incredibly efficient way to work out, but it all hinges on the requirement that you have an insane discipline (and sometimes access to a spotter or certain machines) to go until true failure. No doubt it worked great for Mike because he had the drive to make the program work. The most important thing for amateur lifters is finding a program that works for them. Unless you are competing at an elite level it doesn't matter if you find a program that's 5% or 10% better than another. I like HIT because the workouts are very time efficient, and while repeatedly doing exercises to complete failure can suck ass if you're not feeling it (bad sleep, haven't eaten properly, tired after work etc) the pump you can get from a properly executed HIT failure set is sickening, and as challenging/stimulating mentally as it is physically.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69955240
A good way to avoid the guesswork and uncertainty is to start with a high volume/high intensity program and gradually reduce the volume.
For example: Start with full body every day with every working set to technical failure. When you hit a plateau, you'll know with absolute certainty that it is not due to undertraining. It's due to overtraining. Add a rest day, resulting in full body every other day. When you hit another plateau, add another rest day, and repeat.
This process worked really well for me.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69961334
What we want in a workout is relavent training stimulus. Understand that reps at or very near failure disproportionately tax the system but do not offer an accordingly disproportionate reward other than maybe ensuring that you hit and exceeded a relavent set. That means that sets a few reps from failure allow you to do more sets and get more relavent training volume and notably motor practice with the movement. I tried to get into the high intensity crew for a long time and it was unsustainable. I have trouble stopping sets before failure because it just kinda seems wrong to me, but its the right way to do it. You dont need to get rid of training to failure but just understand that its more like a tool for getting a hard endpoint on where your strength level is. Kinda like a 1RM.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69960762
I like to use blood and guts style HIT for compound lifts. One light warm up set, one set at 50%, one at 70%, and then one working set of 6-8 reps to failure. It really helps me gain strength during a bulk and is great for maintaining strength/muscle while cutting. Last year I benched 250 for a 1RM, this year with that set/rep scheme I benched 250 for 7 reps. I don’t max out anymore though. Too much risk too little reward as a bodybuilder. I’ll save it for the powerlifters.

>>69964384
Yes, and muscle loss is wildly over exaggerated. The point is to put your body into an environment which favors muscle gain, which also happens to be favorable to fat gain, and because fat is unsightly and not what we're interested in we then cut to eliminate it. No, if OP is cycling for heart/general health and fat loss he will not be burning glycogen because the effort will be entirely aerobic.
>>69964301
Don't listen to that other anon, OP. You only burn glycogen if you're cranking up the resistance on the bike, and that won't serve your purpose at all.
Ride bike before hand. It will warm up joints and also help you produce more effort in your workout.
Track your heart rate and don't go over 60% of max heart rate - set resistance very low, lower than you think you need (maybe 1/8th or 1/4 of the maximum scale of resistanve whatever the bike allows) and spin your legs faster to adjust heart rate - somewhere between 80 and 110 rpm is good. This may be difficult at first if its new to you, but within a few sessions you'll find you can go for ages.
Keep it over 20 minutes for an effect, but truthfully 45 minutes minimum is a good time if you're looking to improve health and performance and fat.
Do it every day at gym and make it part of routine.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69964671
Reading leads to thinking, which leads to building your mind.
Then again, if you read books you actually enjoy, you might not get secondary "idea" churning effects, but you're still growing your gray matter. Maybe you have nothing you can relate to the authors you dislike so you don't "get it". Maybe you just think the authors are writing trash for valid reasons.

In effect, if suggested literature doesn't do it for you, find something that does. Try to read the old classics from time to time because you never know when they may pique your curiosity.

>>69963693
There's two types of receptors in your body that will affect how hungry you feel. There's stretch receptors in the stomach and chemoreceptors in your intestines. The stretch receptors will be satisfied when you have enough food volume. These take about 10-15 minutes to register when you've eaten enough so take your time and savor your meals. You can bulk up meals for very little calories with soups, salads, and vegetables in general. The chemoreceptors will be satisfied when you've eaten enough protein, fat, and micronutrients. This one takes a few hours, which is why you're hungry so soon after you eat junk food. Your body can tell you're not giving it enough of the nutrients it wants and needs. If any one of those 3 are missing you'll just be hungry every 1-2 hours and cutting will suck. Eat really high micronutrient-dense foods, eat enough protein, and don't be a retard and ban fats from your food and it'll make things much easier

>>69960811

This this this. It's totally different.
I used to have my feet really far forward on the machine & was doing a bit above parallel with 5 plates for 10 reps, (when the feet are far forward, going further than a certain amount means your lower back comes off the pad which I didn't want). I now have my feet much less forward & do 2 and a half plates a side for 8 reps, ass to grass, bringing my calves to my hamstrings basically. It's a depth I'd never be able to hit on squats with a decent spine position so if it wasn't already apples to oranges it's even more different now. And that super full ROM version is the way I'd argue you're meant to use the machine, frankly.
So depending on your form, your hack squat could involve more or less weight than a barbell squat.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69942800
The issue at hand is that sometimes people have no idea what they're arguing against, or for, because they interchangeably use the words energy/fat, or weight/fat, or muscle/weight, etc etc
Calories in calories out works, but once you include factors such as nutrient malabsorbtion, general inflammation, water weight (which can be influenced by the above or medication), and general metabolic health/fluctuations, it becomes a surface approach that no longer caters to the majority of the population

Regardless - the calories you see on boxes, calorie calculators - those are approximate anyways. Use CICO as a rough guide to figure out where you are actually with your caloric intake, and then further adjust - as it's not a reliable model long term, especially when including someone's health in the process of weight loss/weight gain. The irony within that statement is that someone's health will always be included in a process of weigh loss/gain, hence the factors I mentioned in my first paragraph.

I'm not trying to be a contrarian, but after coaching so many people in the last several years following CICO for the majority of protocols I implemented, i realized i had to only use it as a temporary guiding tool for protocol implementation, rather than the protocol itself.

>>69945357
If you're not even counting your calories, how can you possibly claim that your diet is disproving it?
It's not tautological. It would be very simple to falsify. Under laboratory conditions, feed someone 3000 kcal daily of food. Measure their CO2 respiration, weight change, heart rate, body temperature, etc.
The subject will either gain weight, or burn enough excess energy via insensible activities such as fidgeting, pacing, etc, to use up any excess energy.
You can't "prove CICO" because science doesn't work by what you can prove is true, it works by what you can prove is false.
CICO is a simple heuristic that masks a lot of complexity. Pointing out that there is lots of complexity doesn't invalidate the simplified model.
Yes, your food choices are important. Yes, your lifestyle is important. Yes, your hormones are important.
Ultimately though, all the complicating factors around food and metabolism work in one direction only: they only ever cause you to absorb LESS ENERGY from your food, not more.

>You are essentially saying energy can't be created nor destroyed. Wow, how is that useful? CICO needs to prove that it has worthwhile utility.
Yes, that's the point. CICO is an axiom that says that if you burn more energy than you consume, you will lose weight, and if you burn less energy than you consume, you will gain weight, and if the amount of energy you burn is equal to the amount you consume, your weight will remain the same. That's all it is, nothing more nothing less.
>-You cannot know with accuracy your CI
>-You cannot know with accuracy your CO
>-You cannot know how the type and quantity of CI will affect CO
These are all entirely irrelevant. Let me run you through a thought experiment. Eat the same things every day, with roughly the same portion sizes. Yes, there will still be caloric fluctuations with this, but they're very small and can be ignored. Now, track your weight every day, and monitor your weekly averages to account for fluctuations in water weight. Are you losing weight? Great, it's working. Is your weight increasing or staying the same? Remove some food. Repeat this until you are losing weight at the rate you desire. Boom, you've just cut calories from your diet *without counting a single calorie.* Neat, isn't it? It also simultaneously proves CICO while completely bypassing trying to figure out your CI or CO by instead simply tracking the thing that you actually care about - your weight. Knowing exactly what your CI and CO is isn't important, you simply remove food from your diet until you start losing weight. Simple as.
>Consciously restricting calories below maintenance is not the best way to lose body fat. It's a metabolic negative feedback loop of constant misery. And your progress will reverse as soon as you reach your goals.

>>69956264

I started on 30mg a year ago and have stayed at the same level since, only now I skip weekends if I've got noting pressing to work on.

It took me roughly two weeks for my body to adjust to the effects. My resting heart rate would spike to anywhere between 110-140 bpm in the first few days before stabilizing between 60-80. The appetite suppressing effects also helped me shed weight, which probably helped too. I still sweat noticbly more from my armpits when taking Vyvanse, picrel

Keep in mind as you become acclimated to the medicine, the initial euphoria you're currently feeling will wear off and give way to a more calm, focused feeling, which is preferable anyway.

My advice would be to abstain from caffeine and other stims for now, and avoid consuming acidic foods and drinks within a couple hours of taking Vyvanse.

>>69956264

I got a prescription for it about a year ago. Have been using it inconsistently ever since.

I take 20mg in the morning an hour before food. If I have food (especially a larger breakfast) it'll dampen the effects or prolong the onset of effects. Same if it's a workout day (so I'll take it AFTER a workout).

It took a few weeks for it to settle in. I'm definitely more 'awake' but productivity can still wane if I really don't want to do something. It really just feels like an energy and mood booster for me. I try to limit usage to avoid dose creep, so only on heavy work days or on weekends when I'm doing work on my house.

I don't think I've got any kind of dependence. I can be just as productive on a non-vyvanse day. It just gives me a little more pep.

the key about forearms is not so much different exercises as arm muscles but rather different grips. You really gotta dig in the range of motion and sort of like eccentrize or concentrize it as much as you can, at the wrist.

Practice eccentric and concentric wrist extensions and really try to grip it in such fashions, like almost twisting your wrist out whilst doing exercises like pull-ups, dips etc without obviously wrecking your shit, but that's why you practice the extension first.
And similarly close diamond or like wide grip works more so muscle volume at different parts of the muscle, like go for close if you want a bulkier more volumized look, and wide if you really want to flare that muscle out like a wing kinda giving it that diagonal hill spread.
basically you need to 360 noscope the range of motion and its all in ''the flick of the wrist'' so to speak...

This is written by one of the scientists on the IARC (WHO) report that proclaimed red and processed meats were carcinogenic. Almost the entire panel of experts were vegetarians or vegans happy to ignore evidence
>Most importantly for the IARC report, two major dietary intervention studies that should have contributed to the assessment of the claimed relationship of red meat and cancer were not considered. The first was a study of colon polyps, the precancerous growths that greatly increase the likelihood of developing colon cancer. Almost 1,900 subjects with a recent history of having a polyp removed were divided into a control group that ate their usual diet and a group following a diet characterized by significant decreases in total fat, red, and processed meat along with increases in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and legumes (Schatzkin et al., 2000). Participants were followed for 3 years and at the end of that time, the recurrence of colon polyps was identical in both diet groups. It is possible that the precancerous stage may not have been the proper time for dietary intervention. The Women’s Health Initiative, therefore, studied a low-fat diet, achieved in large part by reducing red- and processed-meat consumption, among almost 49,000 women (Beresford et al., 2006); about 30,000 followed their normal diets and almost 20,000 were assigned to low-fat diets. After 9 years, the rate of colon cancer was almost identical in the low-fat and control-diet groups. These studies strongly suggest that the observational studies are not supported by dietary intervention studies at either the precancerous or malignant tumor stages of colon cancer.

My current brosplit has a shoulder day with all sorts of silly exercises:
>10 reps Seated DB press, following the delt movement (not up and down) in W fashion (full rom rep + half rom rep = 1 rep), superset with unilateral leaning cable lat raises, another set of 10 W's, then cable lat raises for the other side. That's all 1 set with no rest, I do 3 sets of that circuit.
>Regular heavier seated DB press 3x10-12
>Facepulls 3x15
>3 sets DB lat raises x12 superset with heavy "penguins" x20 (fast, quarter rep lat raises)
>3x20 Rear delt exercise with dumbbells while seated and leaning forward, swing them back and try to hold it at the top for each rep. Works best with heavy weights and momentum.
This day is so much fun, I walk out looking like a goofy cartoon character with balloon delts. Warm up your external rotators or you might destroy your supraspinatus with this routine.

Theoretically, yes. But, you're going to suffer. And I don't mean "oh, my tummy is rumbling is a little". I mean every part of your body is going to ache. You're going to get headaches, stomach aches, the works. You're not going to be motivated to do anything. You're just going to want to lie in bed.

Also, you're gonna be cold as tits. The majority of the body's calorie expenditure is in keeping your body temperature stable. When your body detects insufficient calories intake, it starts half-assing that process (among others). You'll notice you start setting your thermostat a few degrees higher. Conversely, when you over-eat, you're hot all the time for the same reason. It's why fatties always have thermostats set to 67f and still sweat like pigs at night. Their body is running hot because its detected a caloric surplus.
